description: Twenty years later, a generation is taking stock of how one event shaped their lives.

title: New in Paperback: The Best of Me and Piranesi
description: SEND FOR ME, by Lauren Fox. (Vintage, 272 pp. $16.95.) Foxs fourth novel, which includes excerpts of letters from her great-grandmother to her grandmother, follows a young Jewish woman in 1930s Germany who leaves her parents behind when she and her husband and young daughter move to the United States to escape the Nazis. Our reviewer, Claire Lombardo, called the authors prose rhythmic and gorgeous.

title: Has the Pandemic Changed Cities Forever?
description: SURVIVAL OF THE CITYLiving and Thriving in an Age of IsolationBy Edward Glaeser and David Cutler

title: Putting Down Roots After Finding Love
description: Isaiah Bryant said he wasnt much for traveling before he met Emily Maretsky.

title: The Second Act of the Vaccine Resistance
description: Only a year ago, cautious speculation had it that life would fully return to normal  perhaps by Thanksgiving of 2021. At the time it felt impossibly far-off, and in retrospect it seems navely optimistic. Few of us could have imagined the extent to which vaccine resistance would assert itself so aggressively, in so many different corners of society.

title: Are We More Polarized? Or Just Weirder?
description: Tyler Cowen is an economist at George Mason University, the co-founder of the blog Marginal Revolution, and host of the podcast Conversations With Tyler. But more than that, hes a genuine polymath who reads about everything, goes everywhere and talks to everyone. Ive known him for years, and while I disagree with him on quite a bit, there are few people I learn more from in a single conversation.

title: Pro Surfing, Riding an Olympic Wave, Aims to Create Year-End Suspense
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.  The vibe on the pier was predictably mellow, even with 10 of the worlds best surfers gathered.

title: No Longer a Weekend-Only Romance
description: If there was one constant in the courtship between Rashmitha Vasa and Varun Murthy, it was distance.

title: Science Alone Cant Heal a Sick Society
description: In the winter of 1848, a 26-year-old Prussian pathologist named Rudolf Virchow was sent to investigate a typhus epidemic raging in Upper Silesia, in what is now mostly Poland.

title: We Truly Have Lost Everything: A Journey Out of Kabul the Day It Fell
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Nadima Sahar, a 36-year-old government official in Kabul, was resigned at first. She would stay, no matter how bad things got. She saw hope in the progress Afghanistan had made over the past two decades. Maybe, she thought, she could push for an inclusive government, with more women and ethnic minorities.

title: The Guests Swam Alongside the Couple
description: Laminate vows was included on the prewedding checklist for Catarina Salvador Esprito Santo Cristovo Neto.

title: An Ultimate Test: Quarantining With His Future In-Laws
description: It was like a version of Modern Family meets Groundhog Day, said Elana Hirsh Widmann, after she and Michael David Schoenbrum settled into her childhood room in Morristown, N.J.

title: Deadly and Untraceable, Ghost Guns Are Becoming More Common in N.Y.
description: Miguel Russo should not have been able to own a gun. He had a felony conviction on his record and had shown signs of mental illness.

title: The Real Meaning of Never Forget
description: The boy clings to the undercarriage of an evacuation plane leaving Kabul. He is a teenage athlete, a soccer player of some renown in Afghanistan, yet sees no future for himself in a homeland now ruled by the Taliban. His only hope is to leave. But as the American C-17 takes off, the boy falls to his death, a dot in the gray sky. The disturbing footage of his fall, which circulated online last month, echoed the iconic image of the falling man, who jumped or fell from the north tower of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Together and in Person: Everybody Dance Now
description: The pandemic brought dance to a halt on multiple fronts, shutting down not only theaters but also the spaces where dancers train. Alongside the gradual return of live performance in New York, dance studios have been making a cautious comeback, as they reopen for in-person classes with safety protocols in place.

title: Tom Daley Is All-Around Gold
description: This summer, when cameras at the Tokyo Olympics zeroed in on the British diver Tom Daley, he was nearly always knitting: by the pool, in the stands, on the bus.

title: When a Divorce Lawyer Plays Cupid
description: When Dr. Roger Gilbert got divorced for a second time back in May 2018, his lawyer, Camille Hemmer, made the case that he would find true love in her longtime friend, Lulu Wong.

title: If You Could Have Any Animal Feature, What Would It Be?
description: What do you know about elephants and their trunks?

title: A Time Capsule in Two Front Pages
description: A day after the horrors of that crystalline blue Tuesday morning 20 years ago, I, like so many, carefully preserved a copy of The New York Times dated Sept. 12, 2001, with its screaming banner headline stretched across the top:

title: Topo Chico Is Well Sourced to Win the Seltzer Wars
description: In just a few years, Topo Chico, the sparkling water sourced from Monterrey, Mexico, went from big in Texas to the bubbliest thing since spiked seltzer.

title: Everything You Need to Know About the Met Gala 2021
description: [The red carpet will be livestreamed on Vogue.com starting at 5:30 p.m. Eastern time on Monday, Sept. 13.]

title: What Happened to That Comb-Over?
description: Joining the pandemic boom in cosmetic tuneups, many follicularly challenged men have used their time away from the office to embark on a fresh new look of their own: a hair transplant.

title: How a Publishing Executive Spends Her Sundays
description: At the beginning of Covid, you could see the evolution of readers needs through what was selling, said Sanyu Dillon, the chief marketing officer for Penguin Random House. It started with a rise in interactive workbooks for children, she said. Later last spring, baking, cooking, dog training and interior design saw an increase, she continued. Last summer was a call for racial justice books after the murder of George Floyd and last fall, political books were popular.

title: Democrats Eye Taxing Stock Buybacks and Partnerships to Pay for Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats are coalescing around imposing a new tax on corporations that buy back their stocks to boost share prices and tightening rules around business partnerships that have allowed rich companies to shield profits from taxation.

title: Help! Were Going to Europe and Havent a Clue Which Masks to Pack.
description: My wife and I are both fully vaccinated and were planning to visit Germany, Austria, the Czech Republic and France next month. I cant seem to find consistent information online as to whether any or all of those countries have mask requirements. There are so many questions: Will fabric masks suffice? Does one have to wear a mask outside? What about respirators like FFP2 or N95 masks? We are happy to comply with the mandates; we just dont know the specifics. Victor

title: Ted Lasso Season 2, Episode 8 Recap: Fathers and Sons
description: Fathers and sons, so tricky, Higgins tells Jamie, before continuing on with an irony the latter doesnt catch: They should really write songs about it.

title: Before a Classy Dinosaur Wedding Came Leukemia and I.V.F.
description: Dr. Kaitlin Flannery and John Mancini were 29 and 28 when they met on Bumble in April 2018. They were both living in Palo Alto, Calif.  she was a resident in anesthesiology at Stanford University, and he was a lead data scientist at a cybersecurity start-up in San Jose. At the time, they couldnt have foreseen the cancer diagnosis that would come less than two years into their relationship.

title: $10 Billion in Student Debt Erased Under Biden, but Calls Grow for More
description: Nearly $10 billion in student loan debt has been wiped away since President Biden took office, the most sweeping attempt to fix badly broken parts of the federal student loan system in at least a decade.

title: How Growing Up in New York After 9/11 Shaped These Muslim Leaders
description: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.

title: The Surprising Origins of #MeToo
description: Four years ago, Tarana Burke was a devoted but little-known activist with a vision for how victims of sexual violence could find empathy and healing.

title: New York Edges Closer to Prepandemic Life, as City Workers Return
description: On Monday, as New York City students fully return to public schools, a less heralded reopening will also take place: The citys entire municipal labor force, the largest in the nation, will return to the workplace.

title: Alec Baldwin, Anna Wintour and Billie Jean King Serve Aces
description: On the first night of the U.S. Open, about 150 philanthropists, tennis royalty and boldfaced fans crowded into the Presidents Box at Arthur Ashe Stadium, not only to watch Naomi Osaka play, but also to support the USTA Foundation and its mission to bring tennis to underprivileged youths.

title: Road Warriors: The Marathon That Looks a Lot Like a Gang War
description: The Yankees were on the TV, but no one in the north Bronx sports bar had their eyes on the game. Some people were wearing pinstripes, sure, but thats because they were dressed up as characters from a fictional gang called the Baseball Furies. A few were drinking whiskey, though most were chugging water. A man in skintight jeans was sucking on a pouch of electrolyte gel. It was going to be a long Saturday night that ended at Coney Island  and the plan was to run there.

title: Bruce Is a Parrot With a Broken Beak. So He Invented a Tool.
description: Many animals are known to use tools, but a bird named Bruce may be one of the most ingenious nonhuman tool inventors of all: He is a disabled parrot who has designed and uses his own prosthetic beak.

title: Can TV Get Big Again?
description: In spring 2019, as Game of Thrones aired its final season, the talk among TV-industry pundits was that the age of dragons was not the only era coming to an end. Thrones, the thinking went, might just be the last big TV series ever: That is, the last blockbuster-level behemoth that would dazzle and focus the obsession of a mass audience.

title: Adam Pendleton Is Rethinking the Museum
description: The Marron Atrium of the Museum of Modern Art is a big, awkward space, a hollow that rises from the second to the sixth floor. Since opening amid MoMAs 2004 expansion, it has hosted many projects  but few as complex as Who Is Queen? by Adam Pendleton, which arrives on Sept. 18.

title: New Development Returns, Along With New Holdouts
description: The developers offered Joe Nastasi, a 73-year-old Sicilian mechanic, millions of dollars in cash, high-rise apartments, even to name their new luxury skyscraper after him  if only he would sell them his nondescript, three-story commercial building in Long Island City, Queens, which was key to building the project.

title: What Car Shows May Look Like, if Car Shows Have a Future
description: MUNICH  Before the pandemic, German car shows looked like this: Automakers competed to occupy the most floor space. Gleaming new models were unveiled to the accompaniment of cheesy light shows. Throngs of mostly male visitors ogled displays of the latest in horsepower and luxury from Wolfsburg, Munich and Stuttgart.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, September 10, 2021
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: Sports Post-9/11 Patriotism Seen as Unifier, and Manipulation
description: Thick soot blanketed everything Bobby Valentines eyes could canvas when he visited ground zero in the early morning hours two days after Sept. 11.

title: New Orleans Built a Power Plant to Prepare for Storms. It Sat Dark for 2 Days.
description: NEW ORLEANS  Linda Williams is used to power outages in her neighborhood, where strong winds often damage the electrical lines that crisscross her street. But Hurricane Ida was different. Within days of losing power, the heat was making her so dizzy that she had to stay in bed.

title: The Met Opera Races to Reopen After Months of Pandemic Silence
description: Tera Willis was backstage at the Metropolitan Opera, painstakingly adding strand after strand of salt-and-pepper hair to a half-finished wig  one of dozens she and her team were racing to finish in time for opening night later this month after the pandemic had kept performers from getting measured until mid-August.

title: New Orleans is coming back from Ida, but rural Louisiana is still struggling.
description: Christine Verdin received numerous photos from friends and family of the destruction Hurricane Ida brought to the rural community of Pointe-aux-Chenes, which runs along a bayou southwest of New Orleans.

title: What They Really Want to Do Is Choreograph
description: When star dancers retire, its always a little sad. And if those dancers are still in their prime, fans can feel an especially acute sense of loss. The performances that wont happen are easy to imagine.

title: Not Just Going Through the Motions
description: Marking is a dancers secret weapon. Think of it as going through the motions of choreography without actually performing it. As the hands glide through the dance, the feet move along its spatial pathways. A finger spinning in the air? That signifies a turn.

title: The Trump Coup Is Still Raging
description: What happened at the Capitol on Jan. 6 was not a coup attempt. It was half of a coup attempt  the less important half.

title: Biden mandates vaccines for workers, saying, Our patience is wearing thin.
description: President Biden on Thursday used the full force of his presidency to push two-thirds of American workers to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, reaching into the private sector to mandate that all companies with more than 100 workers require vaccination or weekly testing.

title: California Moves to Outlaw Stealthing, or Removing Condom Without Consent
description: The California State Legislature this week approved a measure that would make the state the first to outlaw stealthing, the act of removing a condom during sex without a partners consent.

title: Did Nazis Produce These Uranium Cubes? Researchers Look for an Answer.
description: The failure of Nazi Germanys nuclear program is well established in the historical record. What is less documented is how a handful of uranium cubes, possibly produced by the Nazis, ended up at laboratories in the United States.

title: Identifying 9/11 Victims 20 Years Later and the Small Town That Fought Hate: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

title: The Impact of Sept. 11, Twenty Years Later
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Bidens Vaccine Mandate Is a Big Mistake
description: Theres one person that President Biden desperately needs to consult about his new federal vaccine mandate: President-elect Biden.

title: Spain Arrests Former Venezuela Spy Chief Accused of Drug Trafficking
description: MADRID  Venezuelas former intelligence chief has been arrested in Madrid for a second time, almost two years after he evaded an extradition order to the United States to stand trial on drug-trafficking charges.

title: What to Watch for in the N.F.L.s Week 1 Games
description: Whether a product of the pandemic, collateral damage from an eliminated preseason or just the way things go in football, the 2020 N.F.L. season was marred by significant injuries and postponements.

title: Were Going to Take Over the World
description: For years Kevin Roose, a technology columnist for The Times, has been spending a lot of time inside bizarre internet cultures. Corners filled with people who believe that the coronavirus is a hoax or the 2020 election was stolen, or even that Hillary Clinton is a shape-shifting lizard.

title: Inwood Watches Closely as New Zoning Kicks In
description: With the lawsuits settled in favor of change in Inwood, developers have begun nosing into the middle-class northern Manhattan enclave, intent on putting up tall new buildings where they were not permitted before.

title: The Making of a Molotov Cocktail
description: Brooklyn lawyers were arrested on charges that they threw a Molotov cocktail into a police vehicle.

title: Dry weather and high winds raise the risk of new fires in Northern California.
description: Exceptionally dry conditions in Sacramento and other parts of Northern California were expected to complicate firefighters efforts on Friday as they battle about a dozen major wildfires across the state.

title: The Stabbing in Morningside Park
description: Every generation, a crime tells a new story about New York. The murder of Tessa Majors is ours.

title: A Missing Legacy
description: The great crises in U.S. history have often inspired the country to great accomplishments.

title: Come From Away Review: Looking for Light in Somber Times
description: The capture of the Broadway musical Come From Away that is now streaming on Apple TV+ is almost impossible to hate. Unless, that is, you have an aversion to traditional Irish music and nice people.

title: Fans Returned, a Grand Slam Was Chased, and Teenagers Stole the Show
description: It began with a human traffic jam and could end with a Grand Slam. There were unprecedented and initially confusing medical requirements and a massive storm that stranded spectators and flooded courts. Some of the games biggest stars did not play, but a host of intriguing new ones took advantage of their absence and electrified audiences that seemed to make more noise than ever.

title: Germany Investigates Russia Over Pre-Election Hacking
description: BERLIN  The federal prosecutors office in Germany said Friday it was investigating who was responsible for a spate of hacking attempts aimed at lawmakers, amid growing concerns that Russia is trying to disrupt the Sept. 26 vote for a new government.

title: Lebanon Gets New Prime Minister Amid Economic Meltdown
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Najib Mikati, a billionaire telecommunications tycoon, became the prime minister of Lebanon on Friday, seizing the reins for a third time in a country that has been without a government for more than a year while its people careened deeper into an economic abyss.

title: The House will examine the failings of the pandemic rental assistance fund.
description: The vast majority of a $46.5 billion rental assistance fund sits unspent, despite one estimate that puts the number of renters in immediate danger of eviction at two million.

title: Britains economic recovery nearly stalled in July as Delta variant spread.
description: The British economy almost stalled in July, even as most of the final pandemic restrictions were lifted. The services sector, which had been the engine of the economic recovery this year, ground to a halt as the Delta variant spread across the country, forcing people to stay home and consumer spending to decline.

title: Leylah Fernandez and Emma Raducanu Steal Some Grand Slam Spotlight
description: It was no mean feat to come up with a tennis story that could compete with the first serious bid for a mens singles Grand Slam in 52 years.

title: Vaccination mandates are an American tradition, and so is the backlash.
description: As disease and death reigned around them, some Americans declared that they would never get vaccinated and raged at government efforts to compel them. Anti-vaccination groups spread propaganda about terrible side effects and corrupt doctors. State officials tried to ban mandates, and people made fake vaccination certificates to evade inoculation rules already in place.

title: 25th Hour: The Best 9/11 Movie Was Always About New York
description: When Spike Lee came under fire last month for including 9/11 conspiracy theorists in his HBO documentary series NYC Epicenters 9/11-2021, historians and others expressed disappointment that Lee had seemed to give credibility to long-debunked claims. (He subsequently edited them out.) But for those of us whove followed Lees career, and its intersection with that seminal New York event of 20 years ago, the initial decision was especially baffling  as Lee also directed what many consider the quintessential film about post-9/11 New York City.

title: Apartments Built on an Assembly Line
description: What if housing were built more like cars  on an assembly line in a factory?

title: Pfizer and BioNTech will soon seek clearance for vaccine use in children 5 and older.
description: The makers of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine will soon ask regulators for clearance to use it in children 5 and older, and are getting ready to make smaller doses of the vaccine for younger children, according to one of the founders of BioNTech, the German company that developed the vaccine in partnership with Pfizer.

title: This G.O.P. candidates hopes may rest with California Democrats.
description: He was the mayor of San Diego, Californias second-largest city, for the better part of a decade until he reached his term limit last year, praised in some quarters for being an increasingly rare moderate Republican in a state where the G.O.P. has struggled.

title: The furriest sideshow of the recall campaign is the center of a lawsuit.
description: The campaign to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom has been going well for the governor lately. Less so for Tag the bear.

title: Biden Pushes Companies on Vaccine Mandates
description: President Biden on Thursday laid out a wide-ranging plan to tackle the coronavirus pandemic, including requiring companies with more than 100 employees to mandate that their workers get vaccinated or face weekly testing. The move comes as airlines, restaurants and other businesses are already feeling the pain of an economic pullback caused by the Delta variant of the virus. The new rule will affect some 80 million workers.

title: How Californias Recall Laws Could Change
description: The looming recall election of Gov. Gavin Newsom has revealed something of a paradox among Californians: We hold dear our ability to recall elected leaders from office but believe the process by which we do so to be deeply flawed.

title: A Classic Valise Gets a Silvery Sheen
description: When Louis Vuitton, a malletier who got his start as a professional packer for the wife of Napoleon III, founded his namesake Paris-based firm in the mid-19th century, travel was cumbersome, time-consuming and rare. The heavily reinforced trunks he fashioned had to be big enough to hold months worth of belongings and to endure long sea voyages and arduous train trips. But in the years between the world wars, as automobile and commercial air travel proliferated, life on the road became easier and more streamlined, as did the luggage the house produced. During the 1930s, the company began making a trio of boxy poplar-wood-frame suitcases in graduated sizes  the Alzer, the Bisten and the Cort, the last of which has been known since the late 1960s as the Cotteville  covered in the brands monogrammed canvas. The smallest of Louis Vuittons hard-sided porte-habits (at only 16 inches wide), the Cotteville, which, like the larger cases, is adorned with the signature S lock, leather trim and brass fittings, has always been synonymous with on-the-fly luxury. This season, Virgil Abloh, the artistic director of the brands mens wear line, has designed the Cotteville 40 in the houses Mirror Monogram canvas with silvery metal trim and a contrasting pale leather handle. Reflective of a collective craving for travel, the compact suitcase seems perfect for its era: shiny and hopeful, with a nod to the past.

title: Flood Damage From Ida? Your Homeowners Policy Probably Wont Cover That.
description: Was your home damaged by Hurricane Ida? Insurance experts say you should file claims as soon as possible  if you have coverage.

title: With Extreme Weather, Home Insurance Will Cost More. If You Can Get It.
description: Wildfires in California and Oregon. Hurricanes that wreak havoc from the Gulf Coast up to the Northeast. Hail in the Midwest that is so big and falls with such intensity that it punctures roofs.

title: Alice Neels Apartment Is Still a Portrait of the Artist at Work
description: ROOMS ARENT SO important in an Alice Neel painting; her focus was on people. Her work, which attests to the cleareyed compassion Neel felt toward humans of all walks of life, reveals the deep interiority of her subjects through vivid, almost caricature-like renderings  wide-set eyes, dimpled chins, skin mottled in shades of green or blemished with blue-purple veins and exaggerated, spidery fingers. The settings in her artworks are often mere suggestions: the shade of a blue wall, the outline of a sofa  the room receding while the figure remains.

title: Washington allocated $46 billion to help prevent an eviction crisis. What went wrong?
description: When the first wave of coronavirus spread across the country in the spring of 2020, it ravaged the economy, pushing millions of low-income tenants to the brink of eviction. Over the next year, Congress responded with a series of relief packages that included a $46.5 billion fund for emergency rental assistance.

title: Iraqi Detainee Reported Suffering Paralysis at Guantnamo
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  A Marine Corps judge has ordered the medical staff at the wartime prison to submit an emergency report Friday on an Iraqi prisoner who, according to his lawyer, suddenly suffered paralysis and lost the ability to walk.

title: Why Chinas Economy Is Threatened by a Property Giants Debt Problems
description: Every once in a while a company grows so big and messy that governments fear what would happen to the broader economy if it were to fail. In China, Evergrande, a sprawling real estate developer, is that company.

title: Bidens Vaccine Mandate Leaves Businesses Relieved but Full of Questions
description: For months, Molly Moon Neitzel, the founder and chief executive of Molly Moons Homemade Ice Cream in Seattle, has debated whether to require her 180 employees to be vaccinated. On Thursday, when President Biden announced rules that would mandate such requirements, she felt relieved.

title: I Documented Afghanistans Post-9/11 Youth
description: This summer I was on assignment with The New York Times Magazine. Heres what I saw.

title: From the Cradle to the Grave, What Kind of Comfort Do Women Want?
description: In the before-before times, or maybe the before-before-before times, not only prepandemic but also pre-Sept. 11, New York Fashion Week was held in Bryant Park, around the historic anchor of the old garment district and the schmatta land of Seventh Avenue. After awhile the neighbors got annoyed by the flood of fashion people taking over the park, and the tents started to migrate: first to Lincoln Center, then to Spring Studios downtown, and now  well, pretty much anywhere theres some outdoor space for a few hundred people and a cool view. The center did not hold.

title: Shooting Scenes From a Marriage: I Cried Every Day
description: There were days on the shoot for Scenes From a Marriage, a five-episode limited series that premieres Sept. 12 on HBO, when Oscar Isaac resented the crew.

title: Novak Djokovic Is Ready for Another Fight
description: A good fight. A battle.

title: Top Orchestras Have No Female Conductors. Is Change Coming?
description: For years, they have worked their way to the top of the classical music industry. They have confronted stereotypes that they are too weak to lead. They have shared advice about how to deal with sexist comments and even how to dress.

title: The S&P 500 drops for a fifth day, its worst stretch since February.
description: U.S. stocks fell for a fifth straight day on Friday, with the S&P 500 ending the week down 1.7 percent in its longest losing streak since February.

title: A World Cup Every Two Years? Why?
description: This is soccers age of the Big Idea. There is an incessant, unrelenting flow of Big Ideas, ones of such scale and scope that they have to be capitalized, from all corners of the game: from individuals and groups, from clubs and from leagues, from the back of cigarette packets and from all manner of crumpled napkins.

title: Budweiser Treads Carefully in Updated 9/11 Commercial
description: Advertising against a tragic event is a delicate calculation for American companies. Do they acknowledge the occasion and invite accusations of being opportunistic? Do they stay silent and risk appearing out of touch or unpatriotic? What is the border between commemoration and commercialization?

title: The Plagiarism Hunter Terrorizing the German-Speaking World
description: SALZBURG, Austria  They call him the plagiarism hunter. He calls himself meticulous and an addict.

title: Fords exit from India hits workers, dealers and customers.
description: Ford Motors decision to close its Indian operations was met with shock and defensiveness on Friday, after it became the latest American company to close its doors in a country with both tremendous possibilities and high hurdles.

title: Stream These Five Action Films Now
description: For action fans seeking out new movies on streaming, there are plenty of car chases, explosions and fist fights to sift through. We help by providing some streaming highlights.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. Eric Kim has a marvelous, simple recipe in The Times this week for egg rice  (above), or egg on rice, a dish found all over the world.

title: The World Catches Up With Dindga McCannon
description: PHILADELPHIA  The moment you walk through Dindga McCannons purple front door, you enter her artistic world. Theres patterned fabric everywhere: covering the windows and furniture, hanging in the form of quilts, clothing and batiks. Her paintings occupy the walls too, and boxes of prints are stashed under the TV. Any free space seems to be a potential spot for art.

title: Radioheads Kid A Era Outtake, and 13 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: The Roys Summer in Italy
description: On location with the cast of Succession, the most interestingly terrible billionaires on TV.

title: Dry Air and High Winds Amplify Wildfire Risk in Northern California
description: The National Weather Service issued a red flag warning for the Sacramento region and other parts of Northern California through 11 p.m. Friday, as a combination of warm temperatures, very low humidity and strong winds increased the risk of new fires.

title: Judge Orders Apple to Ease Restrictions on App Developers
description: A federal judge on Friday struck a serious blow to Apples control of its App Store, giving companies a way to avoid handing Apple a cut of their app sales and potentially upending a $100 billion online market.

title: Will vaccine mandates slow the pandemic? Yes, scientists say  but not immediately.
description: President Bidens new coronavirus vaccine mandates will have sweeping ramifications for businesses, schools and the political discourse in the United States. But for many scientists, the question is a simpler one: Will these measures turn back a surging pandemic?

title: Brick-and-Mortar Retail in the Age of Covid, and Amazon
description: Brick-and-mortar retailers have been decimated in recent years. First came Amazon. Then the pandemic.

title: U.S. Soccer Ties World Cup Prize Money to Equal Pay Fight
description: Cindy Parlow Cone has sat on both sides of the negotiating table in U.S. Soccers equal pay fight, first as a player for the womens national team and most recently as the federations president. She knows the history. She knows the issues. And she knows the obstacles.

title: Zebras Spotted Roaming Behind Maryland Home
description: Five zebras were filmed walking behind a house in Prince Georges County. The animals have been on the loose since escaping from a nearby farm.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: The late-night hosts returned from their Labor Day break to vent about skyrocketing Covid-19 cases, ivermectin and Texas.

title: The Consolations of Incense
description: IN ANCIENT CHINA, time was measured in spirals of smoke, from incense burning through the night. So time had a scent, of warm, sweet sandalwood, cooling camphor, cypress with its evergreen kiss  and under it all, a char on the air, a memory of something set on fire. A clock could be as simple as a fistful of joss sticks, although more complex versions were engineered over the centuries: trails of fragrant powder smoldering in circular mazes, following a twisting path from noon to noon; incense sticks placed under strings tied with tiny weights that fell and clanged against a metal plate at intervals as the strings burned through.

title: An Incense for Every Occasion
description: The American acid-rock band the Strawberry Alarm Clocks 1967 song Incense and Peppermints inevitably recalls the pervasiveness of scents like patchouli during the hippie era. Occasions, persuasions clutter your mind / Incense and peppermints, the color of time, the lead singer croons. But lyrics like these  co-written by John S. Carter and Tim Gilbert  also nod, if only accidentally, to the widespread use of incense in our own helter-skelter age.

title: Olympics Power Broker Convicted in Forgery Case
description: GENEVA  Ahmad al-Sabah, a Kuwaiti sheikh who for years has been one of the most influential power brokers in global sports, faces more than a year in prison after being convicted in a forgery case in Switzerland.

title: Racing Officials in Kentucky and New York Move to Marginalize Baffert
description: The embattled horse trainer Bob Baffert got bad news on Friday from two prominent corners of the horse racing world.

title: Agencies That Required Vaccines Before Bidens Push See Early Success
description: WASHINGTON  President Bidens new coronavirus vaccination mandates have prompted some backlash, but the two federal departments that already require vaccinations say their actions are doing what they intended: getting more shots in arms.

title: Sustainability, Social Justice, Fashion Shows and What We Wear Next
description: A year ago, when Fashion Week had gone entirely digital, The New York Times gathered four industry power brokers together to wrestle with the question of what the pandemic and its effects meant for the business and what we would wear. People were making all sorts of predictions about sweatpants taking over the world and the future of seasons, shows and sales  not to mention sustainability and social justice.

title: NATO Chief Backs Biden, Saying Europe Was Consulted on Afghanistan
description: BRUSSELS  Pushing back against European complaints that the Biden Administration had failed to consult its allies over the withdrawal from Afghanistan, Jens Stoltenberg, NATOs secretary-general, said those objections were exaggerated and that NATO had given unanimous approval for the withdrawal as far back as April.

title: The Spine Collector
description: For years, a mysterious figure has been stealing books before their release. Is it espionage? Revenge? Or a complete waste of time?

title: Meet My Multiple Mes
description: People with dissociative identity disorder have started presenting their selves on YouTube to rapturous fans.

title: Google Could Be Violating Labor Laws With Pay for Temp Workers
description: In December, a group of Google managers responsible for overseeing thousands of its temporary staff members discovered the company had been underpaying some of those workers for years.

title: Signs of Improvement in the Summer Surge
description: The latest news and data from the team tracking the coronavirus.

title: Scott Rudin in the Wings
description: Is the infamous producer gone for good?

title: Everyone in San Francisco Has Something to Say About Chesa
description: A wave of discontent crashes on a progressive prosecutor.

title: See you in court: G.O.P. governors express outrage and vow to fight Bidens vaccine requirements.
description: Republican governors across the country assailed President Bidens aggressive moves to require vaccinations as an unconstitutional attack on personal freedoms and vowed to sue the administration to block the requirements.

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Tyler Cowen
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like todays episode with Tyler Cowen. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Will You Ever Change?
description: Can face-to-face meetings between a victim and an abuser help a society overwhelmed with bad behavior?

title: A Weeknight Pasta That Finds Freedom in the Familiar
description: LONDON  Whats for dinner?

title: Wonking Out: Im Still on Team Transitory
description: Consumer prices have risen 4.4 percent over the past six months; thats an annualized inflation rate of almost 9 percent, which puts us almost back into 1970s territory. And there are plenty of people out there proclaiming the return of stagflation.

title: The Sound of My Inbox
description: The financial promise of email newsletters has launched countless micropublications  and created a new literary genre.

title: This Salad Is a Party
description: September has arrived, and with it, fall home cooking. I know, youre probably still eating tomatoes. I am too. (We had this number for dinner on Wednesday. So good.) I like this shoulder season, when youre maybe still eating giant, lively salads for dinner, but theyre a little heftier and not born of humid desperation to just cool off.

title: Klaus Biesenbach Leaving Los Angeles Museum for Post in Berlin
description: LOS ANGELES  In yet another round of upheaval at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, Klaus Biesenbach, the museums artistic director and former director, is leaving for Berlin to run the Neue Nationalgalerie and the future Museum of the 20th Century, the Berlin museum announced Friday morning.

title: Newsom opens a double-digit lead in polls as the election deadline nears.
description: When the campaign to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom qualified for the ballot in April, Democrats scoffed. It was a futile piece of theater from the far right, they said. California is, after all, one of the bluest states in the country.

title: Toyota to cut production 40% in October because of the chip shortage.
description: Toyota Motor said on Friday that it will make about 40 percent fewer cars and trucks around the world in October as a result of complications from a shortage of computer chips and Covid-19 restrictions affecting the production of parts in Southeast Asia.

title: Malignant Review: Womb for Improvement
description: The acting in Malignant might be on the hokey side, but who goes to a James Wan movie for the performances? What we want is gore and goose bumps, and in that regard, Malignant doesnt entirely disappoint. Even if we have to wait until roughly 17 minutes before the finale to experience peak splatter.

title: Senate Aides Try to Sway Rules Enforcer Over Including Immigration Overhaul in Budget Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Republican aides challenged their Democratic counterparts on Friday in a debate before the Senates top rules enforcer that could determine whether as many as eight million undocumented immigrants have a path to citizenship.

title: Have At It, Biden Tells Republicans Threatening to Challenge Mandate
description: A day after unveiling a plan to push two-thirds of American workers to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, President Biden suggested the mandates would withstand Republican efforts to defy them.

title: Map: Tracking Larrys Path
description: A map showing the storms route as it approached eastern Canada.

title: Biden Tests Limits of Presidential Power in Pushing Vaccinations
description: WASHINGTON  President Bidens far-reaching assertion of executive authority to require Covid-19 vaccines for 100 million American workers relies on a set of complicated legal tools that will test the power  and the limits  of the federal government to compel personal health care decisions.

title: 20 Years Later: My Journey as a 9/11 Survivor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Texas Abortion Law Creates a Kind of Bounty Hunter. Heres How It Works.
description: The new law in Texas effectively banning most abortions has ignited widespread controversy and debate, in part because of the mechanism it uses to enforce the restrictions: deputizing ordinary people to sue those involved in performing abortions and giving them a financial incentive to do so.

title: Big 12 Gets 4 New Members in College Sports Latest Shuffle
description: In another sign of a precarious era of realignment in college sports, the Big 12 Conference moved Friday to add Brigham Young University, Cincinnati, Houston and the University of Central Florida, with the colleges able to join as early as 2023.

title: The Return of FOMO
description: The pandemic forced us to simplify our lives and look inward. Now its time to have fun again. That should be easy, right?

title: Doing the Work at Work
description: What are companies desperate for diversity consultants actually buying?

title: The F.D.A. again warns parents not to get children under 12 vaccinated yet.
description: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration is working around the clock to make Covid vaccines available to young children, it said in a statement on Friday. In the meantime, however, the agency urged parents not to seek out the shots for children who are under 12, and therefore not yet eligible for vaccination.

title: New York Fashion Week: Day 3
description: Fashion Week is back in full force, and theres a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and youll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. Every day well spotlight one thing we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.

title: 9/11 Reflections: The Tears Still Come
description: To the Editor:

title: The Destroy-It-to-Save-It Plan for East River Park
description: The city says the only way to protect the park from the next Sandy is to bury it.

title: New York City Made the Office
description: And the office, in turn, made modern New York.

title: Need a Little Sunshine? This Weeknight Fish Has It in Spades.
description: When I saw a copy of Danielle Alvarezs cookbook, Always Add Lemon, I knew Id found a kindred spirit in the kitchen.

title: Michel Laclotte, Who Created the Modern Louvre, Dies at 91
description: Michel Laclotte, who as director of the Louvre oversaw much of its historic renovations, and who earlier, as its chief curator of paintings, championed the Muse DOrsay (the museum-in-a-train-station) and I.M. Peis glass pyramid at the Louvre  two of the most controversial but ultimately beloved architectural projects of late-20th-century Paris  died on Aug. 10 in Montauban, in southern France. He was 91.

title: Love Letter: Learning to Keep It Chill
description: It took a failed attempt at coercing a casual hookup into a relationship for Coco Mellors, the writer of this weeks Modern Love essay, to see that her anxiety and abandonment issues caused her to chase emotionally unavailable men. With the help of a Buddhist teacher, a therapist and a new love interest, she finally understood that love didnt have to hurt.

title: The Weekender
description: Why booming Utah is seeing more air pollution. Also in this edition: how a Cupid surfaced in a famous artwork and an interview with Colson Whitehead.

title: The End of Kimyes Wild Ride
description: She thought he was an artistic genius. He proclaimed wanting to dip her in gold. And now its over.

title: The Original Sandernista
description: For richer or poorer, Jane Sanders married a movement.

title: Mattel dusts off He-Man, with a nod to diversity.
description: When Mattel introduced the brawny superhero He-Man in 1982, he was an instant hit. Four years later, at the peak of its popularity, sales of the sword-and-sorcery toy line soared to $400 million in the U.S.

title: Joe Bidens First 100 Days Reshaped America
description: President Bidens advantage is that hes not just nice; hes also tedious. He is relentlessly enacting an ambitious domestic agenda  such as, expanding Obamacare and signing a $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan  while arousing hardly any controversy.

title: Welcome to the Trump Book Expo
The Soul of Bravo
description: A year of national reckonings on race and inequality has tested how real the Housewives should be.

title: Once, Twice, Thrice Upon a Time
description: THE LITTLE WOODEN ROBOT AND THE LOG PRINCESSWritten and illustrated by Tom Gauld

title: How Some Women Are Remaking the Workplace to Better Suit Their Lives
description: Ellen Ernst Kossek, a professor at Purdue University, studying work-life boundaries

title: An appeals court allows Florida to continue its ban on school mask mandates for now.
description: Floridas ban on school mask mandates can remain in place while a legal challenge makes its way through the courts, an appeals court ruled on Friday. It reverses the decision of a lower court judge who had put the ban on hold and allowed the states largest school districts to require face coverings amid a deadly coronavirus surge.

title: Lis Left Standing
description: Win or lose, Pete Buttigiegs senior adviser Lis Smith has turned an unknown mayor into a serious contender.

title: Brandon Taylor on the Sally Rooney Phenomenon
description: The novelist Brandon Taylor, who has generated his own buzz with his debut novel, Real Life, and a collection of stories, Filthy Animals, visits the podcast to discuss the much-discussed work of Sally Rooney. Taylor recently reviewed her third novel, Beautiful World, Where Are You. On the podcast, he describes Rooneys writing as an intense, melancholic tractor beam.

title: Boriss Blundering Brilliance
description: Brexit has given the U.Ks self-seeking Prime Minister the opportunity to show he actually knows what hes doing.

title: Theres Always Been More to Kirsten Dunst
description: The main things Kirsten Dunst wanted out of her trip to Italy were to sleep soundly on the plane and to drink a Bellini upon arrival. She would have considered anything else to be a bonus and, as it turned out, those bonuses were considerable.

title: What Should We Do About Systemic Racism?
description: Heres why some people arent onboard with the way Americans are taught to think about systemic racism: Even fully understanding that systemic racism exists and why it is important  persistent disparities between Black people and others in access to resources  one may have some questions. Real ones.

title: The Limits of My Empathy for Covid Deniers
description: I recently drove by an anti-vaccine rally just outside Winston-Salem, N.C. It was not very populated. There were maybe a half-dozen people with signs and more onlookers than protesters. Drivers honked their car horns  whether in solidarity or disgust, I could not tell.

title: Should Giving a Bribe Be Legal?
description: A decade ago, Kaushik Basu, a Cornell University economist, caused a furor in India when he proposed that for a certain class of bribes, the act of giving a bribe should be considered legal. Basu, who at the time was the chief economic adviser to Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, described the reaction in his 2016 book, An Economist in the Real World: The Art of Policymaking in India:

title: Youre Not the Mean Lady at Work
description: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

title: Buffalo Soldiers, the Famed Black Cavalry, Get a Statue at West Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  A large crowd watched expectantly as a soldier tugged at a black cloth spread over a monumental statue on the grounds of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point on Friday morning. As it fell away, it revealed a bronze statue of a Black soldier sitting astride a stallion, a tribute to the U.S. Armys famed Black cavalry  the Buffalo Soldiers  who for decades taught military horsemanship to white cadets here.

title: Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: In a text accompanying Martine Symss exhibition Loot Sweets, the writer Alissa Bennett recounts Syms texting her photos from a Beverly Hills auction of iconic treasures that originally belonged to the singer Janet Jackson. The body of Janet seemed evident everywhere in these pictures, Bennett writes, the full arc of her life indicated by an accumulation of personal property that had no value whatsoever outside of the violence of our desire.

title: Harvard Says It Will Not Invest in Fossil Fuels
description: Harvard University has announced that it does not intend to make any future investments in fossil fuels, and is winding down its legacy investments because, the universitys president, Lawrence S. Bacow, said in an email to the Harvard community, climate change is the most consequential threat facing humanity.

title: Trevor Bauers Season Ends With Extension of His Leave
description: Trevor Bauer, the star pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers who remains under investigation for sexual assault, will not pitch in the majors again this season. Major League Baseball and the players union agreed Friday to extend his administrative leave until the end of the postseason, a league official said.

title: How a U.S. Drone Strike Killed the Wrong Person
description: A week after a New York Times visual investigation, the U.S. military admitted to a tragic mistake in a drone strike in Kabul last month that killed 10 civilians, including an aid worker and seven children.

title: Times Investigation: In U.S. Drone Strike, Evidence Suggests No ISIS Bomb
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It was the last known missile fired by the United States in its 20-year war in Afghanistan, and the military called it a righteous strike  a drone attack after hours of surveillance on Aug. 29 against a vehicle that American officials thought contained an ISIS bomb and posed an imminent threat to troops at Kabuls airport.

title: Its a Brawl in Beantown, as Progressive Allies Clash in the Boston Mayors Race
description: BOSTON  Not so long ago, Bostons leading progressives called themselves sisters in service, linking arms to take on this citys overwhelmingly white, overwhelmingly male old guard.

title: In Colson Whiteheads New Novel, a Crime Grows in Harlem
description: Sometimes he slipped and his mind went thataway, Colson Whitehead writes about Ray Carney, the crime-adjacent Harlem furniture salesman at the center of his new novel, Harlem Shuffle. Whiteheads own mind has famously gone thataway through nine other books that dont much resemble one another, but this time hes hit upon a setup that will stick. He has said he may keep Ray going into another book, and it wont take you long to figure out why.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Welcome. Tomorrow morning Im going to meet my friend Daniel for breakfast in the East Village, and then were going to walk over to the west side, roughly following the route I traveled to work on Sept. 11, 2001, when Daniel and I were colleagues at the then-brand-new cable network Oxygen. The office had a bank of about eight televisions in its lobby, each regularly tuned to a different news channel. That day, as we entered, each showed the exact same images.

title: Say Hello to the Tortizza, a Dinner Life Raft
description: When it first opened in 2018, the Manhattan bar and vodka distillery Our/New York would serve makeshift tortilla pizzas that had been quickly burnished in a toaster oven behind the bar. The founder and partner, Dave Ortiz, got the idea from his friend, the chef Ilan Hall. Long story short: A celebrity chef hooked me up, he said.

title: A New Podcast Rekindles a Box-Office Bomb
description: One day last December, Julie Salamon was sorting through stacks of old plastic boxes at a storage unit in Lower Manhattan. Salamon, 68, is a journalist, author and self-described pack rat. The boxes were accidental galleries in the museum of a lifes work, filled with relics  notebooks, clippings, photos and tapes  accumulated for the dozen books Salamon has published since 1988.

title: Whats Going on With Our Black Girls? Experts Warn of Rising Suicide Rates.
description: For more than a decade, suicide rates have been increasing in Black children and adolescents, and a new study says the sharpest rise occurred among young girls.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The sweeping vaccine mandates that President Biden announced yesterday will affect almost every aspect of society in the United States. Our colleague Apoorva Mandavilli, who covers science for The Times, had a simple question: Will the mandates slow the surging pandemic?

title: Carl Bean, Gay Singer Who Turned to Preaching, Dies at 77
description: Carl Bean, who in 1977 recorded I Was Born This Way, a disco song of L.G.B.T.Q. pride that became a much-remixed club favorite  and who then became a minister and AIDS activist, founding a church in Los Angeles that sought to serve the spiritual needs of gay people and others who were marginalized  died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 77.

title: Top National Security Posts Sit Empty, Mired in Senate Purgatory
description: WASHINGTON  Before the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, nearly half of the federal governments Senate-confirmed top national security jobs sat empty, making the United States more vulnerable, the 9/11 Commission found. Two decades later, the situation  by at least one measure  is worse.

title: Sept. 11, Vaccines, the Met Opera: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Israel Captures 4 of 6 Palestinian Fugitives Who Escaped Prison
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli police said on Saturday that they had captured four of the six Palestinian fugitives who escaped a maximum-security prison this week, in a case seen as a rare humiliation of the countrys security establishment.

title: A Sept. 11 Conundrum
description: A lot of important words are being written about the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks on America, marking that major and tragic turning point in history.

title: U.S. Forces Were Training the Guinean Soldiers Who Took Off to Stage a Coup
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  American Green Berets were training local forces in the West African nation of Guinea last weekend when their charges peeled away for a mission not listed in any military training manual: They mounted a coup.

title: Debate Over Guns Is Muted as Canadas Election Nears
description: With the debates now over, we have come to the final days of the high-speed election campaign that was called last month by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

title: Food Delivery Apps Sue New York Over Fee Limits
description: The three largest food delivery platforms have filed a lawsuit seeking to overturn New York Citys cap on the fees they can charge to restaurants.

title: Bank of America Revamps Leadership, but C.E.O. Plans to Stick Around
description: Bank of America made sweeping changes to the companys leadership Friday that elevated several executives, including three women, to senior jobs and all but guaranteed that Brian Moynihan, the chief executive, would remain at the helm of the nations second-largest bank for years to come.

title: The Afghan War Took an Awful Toll. I Would Still Serve Again.
description: Was it worth it?

title: Two People Injured in Fire at a Queens Hospital
description: Two people suffered minor injuries after a fire erupted on the roof of St. Johns Episcopal Hospital in Queens on Friday, fire officials said.

title: Daniil Medvedev Easily Advances to U.S. Open Final
description: When Daniil Medvedev made his first U.S. Open final two years ago, he did it to a soundtrack of frequent boos, leaning into a villain role he acquired during a contentious third-round match and goading the crowd before ultimately winning it over with his valorous losing effort in the final against Rafael Nadal.

title: The Taliban Are Telling Us They Havent Changed at All
description: For weeks, the Taliban promised to unveil an inclusive government: one that would respect womens rights, albeit within the confines of Shariah; represent different ethnicities; and bar terrorist groups from Afghanistan.

title: Federal Research Bolsters the Case for Vaccine Mandates
description: Just a day after President Biden issued broad mandates aimed at encouraging American workers to get vaccinated against the coronavirus, federal health officials released new data showing that unvaccinated Americans are 11 times as likely as vaccinated people to die of Covid-19.

title: Video Shows Fire at New York City Hospital
description: The blaze erupted on the roof of St. Johns Episcopal Hospital in Queens. Officials said that the flames were extinguished within an hour and that two people suffered minor injuries.

title: Bidens Vaccine Push Aligns Him With a Fed-Up, Vaccinated Majority
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  Terry Orie, a 61-year-old real estate agent, has skipped vacations because of the pandemic. She has canceled plans with friends. She has bristled at the frustrations of communicating with clients when everybody is wearing masks.

title: The Overlooked Costs of Counterterrorism
description: The consequences of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and the decades of war that followed can in some ways be quantified: nearly a million lives lost, 38 million people displaced as a result of conflict, an estimated $8 trillion in expenditures and 85 countries affected to varying degrees by American counterterrorism operations.

title: Biden Is Right: Vaccine Refusal Has Cost All of Us
description: As Americans contemplate the prospect of a second winter trapped in the grip of Covid-19, remember that it didnt need to be this way. Vaccines were developed in record time, and have proved to be both incredibly safe and stunningly effective. Nearly two-thirds of eligible Americans have accepted these facts and done their part by getting fully vaccinated.

title: Bidens Sweeping Vaccine Mandates Infuriate Republican Governors
description: President Bidens orders pushing millions of workers to get vaccinated were aimed at turning the tide on a pandemic that has killed 650,000 Americans. But on Friday, the mandates immediately deepened the nations political divisions over coronavirus vaccinations and government power.

title: Measles Cases Bring Temporary Halt to Afghans Arrival in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The Biden administration halted flights carrying Afghan evacuees to the United States from military bases overseas after discovering a few of the new arrivals had measles, the latest hurdle in a haphazard effort to assist allies hoping to flee the Taliban.

title: 20 Years On, the War on Terror Grinds Along, With No End in Sight
Biden Doubled Mask Fines. What Does It Mean for Air Passengers?
description: On Thursday, in a wide-ranging speech outlining aggressive steps to curb the spread of the coronavirus, President Biden announced that the Transportation Security Administration would double fines for travelers who refuse to wear masks in airports and on commercial airplanes.

title: Cause for Alarm?
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  The last time we solved a Sid Sivakumar grid in The New York Times, it was a collaboration with Matthew Stock back in May, another challenging fanned-out construction. This kind of geometric pattern, combined with Saturday cluing, means that a solver has four isolated propellers to flail away at; the momentum I built in the southwest quadrant did nothing for me in the northwest, which was by far my weakest spot.

title: Novak Djokovic Reaches U.S. Open Final, One Victory From a Grand Slam
description: Twenty-seven down, one to go.

title: Quotation of the Day: Buffalo Soldiers Get Statue at West Point
description: When I was coming up we had no role models that we could talk to. We didnt know we had Buffalo Soldiers. If we had known about that it would have made a difference. Now they have a historical, tangible reference point.

title: His Basketball Camp Made Hall of Famers. Now Hes One, Too.
description: Grant Hill was introduced to the Five Star Basketball Camp in the form of a Sports Illustrated article that was published in 1984, when he was 11 years old. As Hill flipped through the pages of the magazine, he found himself transfixed. To him, Five Star sounded like basketball nirvana, an exclusive destination where promising players could consume the game.

title: Looking Back, I Am Glad We Played
description: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.

title: Corrections: Sept. 11, 2021
description: An article on Friday about security trading in 2020 by Federal Reserve officials misstated the timing of stock disclosures by Randal K. Quarles and Jerome H. Powell. Mr. Quarless disclosure was made in 2020, for 2019 transactions. His transactions were not made last summer. And Mr. Powells disclosures of 41 transactions were for 2019, not 2020.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: SATURDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Remembering 9/11
description: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you dont already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

title: Always Pay the Rent? It May Help Your Mortgage Application.
description: Later this month, a group of renters in the United States will get a new break when they try to become homeowners: Their history of consistently paying their landlords will count toward qualifying for a mortgage.

title: In Shanksville, Preserving the Memory of 9/11 and the Wars That Followed
description: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.

title: Meeting Hungarys Strongman, Pope Treads a Fine Line With an Embattled Leader
description: BUDAPEST  Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary portrays himself as the defender of Christian Europe against migrants and multiculturalism. After years of his weakening of democratic institutions, the far-right strongman has prepared for coming elections in Catholic-majority Hungary by strengthening his links to Catholic traditionalists in Europe and the United States.

title: How 9/11 Changed a 13-Year-Old Girl in Harlem
description: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.

title: Newsoms Strategy for California Recall: Its Me or the Abyss
description: SACRAMENTO  As the campaign to oust him heads into its final weekend, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California is hammering home the choice he has presented to voters since the start of the recall  Donald J. Trump or him.

title: To Survive the Pandemic, a Secret Nintendo Cafe Is Secret No Longer
description: TOKYO  Toru Hashimoto ran a cafe he hoped almost nobody could find.

title: Mountain of Money Fuels Gavin Newsoms Surge to Recall Finish Line
description: Gov. Gavin Newsoms bid to fend off a recall in California has been bolstered by an infusion of tens of millions of dollars from big donors in recent months that delivered him an enormous financial advantage over his Republican rivals in the races final stretch.

title: Berlin Clubs Return With a Vengeance
description: BERLIN  The beats were pumping inside Salon zur wilden Renate long after the sun had risen. Hundreds of euphoric, maskless revelers crammed onto the dance floor, the only social distancing created in temporary pockets by the rhythmic moving of the crowd.

title: How Math Solved the Case of the Volcanic Bombs That Didnt Explode
description: It would be reasonable to hear the term volcanic bomb and presuppose that such an object tends to explode. But a specific type of volcanic bomb rarely lives up to the second half of its name: These objects get blasted into the air, crash into the ground and disappointingly fail to detonate.

title: Everything Changed Overnight: Afghan Reporters Face an Intolerant Regime
description: Beloved shows removed from the airwaves. A television station cutting from a news report a story about a pregnant police officer who was reportedly fatally shot by the Taliban. A radio editor telling his colleagues to edit out anti-Taliban cheers from coverage of demonstrations in the capital.

title: Vaccine Resisters Seek Religious Exemptions. But What Counts as Religious?
description: When Crisann Holmess employer announced last month that it would require all employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19 by Nov. 1, she knew she had to find a way out.

title: Trump May Be Gone, But the Fight Against His Border Wall Goes On
description: LOS EBANOS, Texas  The men showed up unannounced, but it didnt take long for Aleida Flores Garcia to figure out why they were measuring portions of her backyard. We are here to mark where a border wall would go, they told her last summer as they surveyed the ranch her family has owned for five generations.

title: The Photographs of 9/11
description: In 2002, The New York Times won the Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Photography for its coverage of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath. Two decades later, we asked our photographers to return to their work from that time and reflect on the images they created, and what it took to capture them. Their answers have been edited for length and clarity.

title: Its a Godsend: 9-Cent Taxi Rides in Rural South Korea
description: SEOCHEON, South Korea  On a recent overcast morning, a village on South Koreas west coast showed no sign of human stirring until five older residents slowly emerged through the fog that shrouded lush, green rice paddies.

title: Special Episode: What Does It Mean to Never Forget?
description: Two planes hijacked by Al Qaeda pierced the north and south towers of the World Trade Center. A third slammed into the Pentagon in Arlington, Va. A fourth crashed in an open field outside Shanksville, Pa. All in less than 90 minutes.

title: History on the Line at the U.S. Open Finals
description: Theres an unexpected all-teenage womens final, and the mens top seeds meet with a Grand Slam on the line.

title: Quandary at U.N.: Who Speaks for Myanmar and Afghanistan?
description: Myanmars brutal military coup and the Talibans triumphal return to power in Afghanistan are among the crises confronting the United Nations as it convenes its annual General Assembly this coming week.

title: For a Fractured Israel, a Film Offers Ominous Lessons From Ancient Past
description: JERUSALEM  A gripping political thriller swept across cinema screens in Israel this summer, with the movie prompting impassioned debate and striking a particularly resonant chord with Israels precarious new government.

title: Unearthed at a British Golf Course: A Log Coffin From the Bronze Age
description: In July 2018, Hugh Willmott was overseeing the excavation of an Anglo-Saxon burial site in northeast England when a regional preservation official told him about a potentially more exciting find.

title: The pandemic is a key issue in the recall, and that bodes well for Newsom.
description: Just a few months ago, when it seemed as though the worst of the coronavirus pandemic was behind us, Republican supporters of the recall felt vindicated and optimistic. The fact that so many people were out and about would only embolden the argument that Gov. Gavin Newsom had been too tough in his lockdown orders last year.

title: At 9/11 museum, site of todays memorial, controversies past and present.
description: The 9/11 Memorial & Museum in Lower Manhattan, the host of this mornings ceremony, is no stranger to controversy, whether before its 2014 opening or in recent days.

title: Nickolas Davatzes, Force Behind A&E and the History Channel, Dies at 79
description: Nickolas Davatzes, who was instrumental in creating the cable television networks A&E and the History Channel, which now reach into 335 million households around the world, died on Aug. 21 at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 79.

title: How Can I Figure Out What Repairs a Building Might Need in the Future?
description: Q: Im considering buying a new place, and I want to know how a prospective buyer of a co-op or condo in New York can find out what repairs the building might need in the next four or five years. Id hate to be hit with a huge assessment for repairs shortly after I move in, and I certainly dont want to unknowingly move into a building with structural problems.

title: The C.D.C. reports that unvaccinated Americans are 11 times more likely to die if infected: The week in Covid news.
description: Unvaccinated Americans were 4.5 times more likely than vaccinated individuals to become infected with the coronavirus, and they were 10 times more likely to be hospitalized and 11 times more likely to die from it, according to one among a handful of studies highlighting the effectiveness of the shots.

title: A Nick to Apples Profits Could Be a Windfall for App Developers
description: Apple has taken to calling its iPhone App Store an economic miracle, and it has pointed to developers like Zach Shakked as proof.

title: Tributes to Sept. 11 victims, survivors, and families from around the world
description: As the United States marks the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, memorials have been held around the world, and tributes have been paid by global leaders, in memory of the victims, survivors and families affected.

title: Manning Up, Letting Us Down
description: WASHINGTON  Im not one of those people who think women make naturally better leaders than men, more collegial and collaborative. Ive covered enough women in the upper ranks, and worked for and with enough women, to know that it depends on the individual.

title: Venus Williams: The Thing That Has Really Made Me Tough
description: Im sitting at my desk after having to pull out of this years U.S. Open with a leg injury. Managing physical ailments is always difficult, but its part of a professional athletes job. I have always understood this.

title: The Unnecessary Cruelty of Americas Immigration System
description: One day in the spring of 2019, a young Honduran man in a detention center in Ferriday, La., began to feel strange. Hed recently heard from his lawyers that his request to be released on humanitarian parole while his asylum case was pending had been denied. As he swayed on his feet, his skin breaking out into hives, he suspected that the stress of facing more time in a prison cell had brought on a panic attack.

title: The Sacklers Are Walking Off Into the Sunset. Reform the System.
description: On Sept. 26, 2019, the Department of Justice appointed me to serve on the Official Unsecured Creditors Committee in the bankruptcy case against Purdue Pharma, the company that helped fuel the opioid overdose crisis through the misbranding and reckless marketing of the powerful painkiller OxyContin. The committee acted as a mega-plaintiff, with broad powers to subpoena records, take depositions and cross-examine witnesses. For nearly two years, I attended countless negotiations, depositions and chambers meetings. I read thousands of pages of confidential documents revealing the true nature and depth of Purdues liability in the crisis.

title: At 9/11 Ceremonies, Moments of Silence, Tributes and Tears
description: The loved ones gathered again in Lower Manhattan for moments of silence and the peals of the bells. They paid tribute to those they lost 20 years earlier and listened as Bruce Springsteen sang about memory and loss.

title: Violent extremists at home and abroad are children of the same foul spirit, George W. Bush says in Pennsylvania.
description: Former President George W. Bush commemorated the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on Saturday at the Flight 93 National Memorial in Pennsylvania, recalling a time of American unity and drawing a sharp contrast with the present-day divisiveness of the countrys politics.

title: What Can Sports Teach Us?
description: Good morning, and welcome to the first issue of my newsletter (you are reading the web version), a place where I hope to discuss the obsessions, ideas and thought processes that have shaped and guided my career.

title: New York Fashion Week: Day 4
description: Fashion Week is back in full force, and theres a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and youll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. Every day well spotlight one thing we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.

title: In Chicago, people climb steps to remember emergency workers lost on 9/11.
description: More than 500 people, many of them firefighters in full uniforms, climbed 2,200 steps at Chicagos Soldier Field on Saturday to remember the victims of Sept. 11.

title: As Democrats Push a $3.5 Trillion Bill, a Top Lawmaker Stays Mum on Tax Increases
description: WASHINGTON  When Republicans sought to pass a giant tax cut along party lines in 2017, Representative Richard E. Neal of Massachusetts, the top Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, led his partys effort to brand the legislation as a tax break for the rich, helping erode public support for the bill.

title: Abimael Guzmn, Leader of Guerrilla Group That Terrorized Peru, Dies at 86
description: Abimael Guzmn, the founder and leader of the Shining Path guerrilla movement, which spread terror across much of Peru in the 1980s and 90s, died on Saturday in Peru. He was 86.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: ACROSTIC  Once again, Team Cox-Rathvon presents a passage that speaks to me personally: I have a scar on my right leg from one of the evil, evil plants that we read about today, and the author of the passage doesnt sound too fond of them, either. That author is Mary Hunter Austin, a naturalist who wandered alone through the Southwest in the 19th century, encountering all manner of desert fauna and flora (in heavy skirts, and hopefully unscathed). The passage comes from a book called The Land of Little Rain, published in 1903; Austin meets with adversity but also expresses admiration for yuccas, coyotes, cactuses and everything that scratches out a life in such harsh environs.

title: Parents of Young Children Desperately Seek Vaccine Trials
description: Leng Vong Reiff had just received her second dose of a Covid vaccine and thought guiltily of her two young, unvaccinated sons. So she began banging away at her keyboard.

title: Phony Diagnoses Hide High Rates of Drugging at Nursing Homes
description: The handwritten doctors order was just eight words long, but it solved a problem for Dundee Manor, a nursing home in rural South Carolina struggling to handle a new resident with severe dementia.

title: Kamala Harris: 9/11 shows how fear can be used to sow division.
description: At a memorial for the passengers who fought back against terrorists aboard United Airlines Flight 93, Vice President Kamala Harris warned that the tragedy of the Sept. 11 attacks had shown how fear can be used to sow division, and stressed that Americas diversity was its greatest asset.

title: On the Scene: 9/11 at Guantnamo Bay
description: At Guantnamo Bay, the memory of Sept. 11 is never far away. And not just because the men who are accused of plotting the terrorist attacks are held prisoner here.

title: At Pro-Taliban Protest, a Symbol of Americas Lost Influence: Faces Obscured by Veils
description: Hundreds of women, many wearing full-length robes, their faces obscured by black veils, filled the auditorium of a Kabul university on Saturday holding signs  many of them in English  in support of the Taliban and its strict interpretation of Islam, including separate education for men and women.

title: All of the names of those lost in the 9/11 attacks were read out loud.
description: The names of the nearly 3,000 lives lost in the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, were read out loud by family members at a ceremony in Lower Manhattan.

title: What the recall means for the future of mail-in voting.
description: More than a third of Californias active registered voters had cast their ballots in the recall election by Saturday, several days before polls close.

title: Unity Is Imperative in America, Harris Says at 9/11 Ceremony
description: Vice President Kamala Harris highlighted the importance of unity in America during a memorial service near Shanksville, Pa., for the victims of Flight 93 who were killed 20 years ago.

title: Wheres Trump on 9/11? Not at ground zero.
description: Notably absent from the 9/11 memorial ceremonies on Saturday was former President Donald J. Trump, a native New Yorker who built much of his political brand in the divisive aftermath of the attacks.

title: At Selfridges, Weddings Are on the Fourth Floor
description: LONDON  When Carlene Noel and Danny Sains exchanged vows on Saturday they werent just merging their two families into one, they were also marking an unusual expansion of the offerings of a British department store. The new Mr. and Ms. Sains got married on the fourth floor of the stately flagship of Selfridges, on Londons Oxford Street.

title: Teresa Zylis-Gara, Plush-Voiced Polish Soprano, Is Dead at 91
description: Teresa Zylis-Gara, a Polish soprano who displayed a plush voice, impressive versatility and beguiling stage presence during a three-decade international career that included a stretch at the Metropolitan Opera during her prime in the 1970s, died on Aug. 28 in Lodz, Poland. She was 91.

title: What Comes After the 9/11 Era?
description: When I moved to Washington, D.C., in 2002 we all lived in 9/11s shadow. We waited for bombs in the Metro, for more anthrax envelopes, for a sequel to the previous autumns terror. We watched planes headed for Reagan Airport fly low over the Potomac, always half-expecting them to veer.

title: Painful memory for Muslims: Outrage over a proposed Islamic center in Manhattan.
description: To the two men who envisioned it, an Egyptian-American real estate developer and an imam long involved in interfaith initiatives, Park51 was a simple but necessary project: a Muslim community center, modeled on the Jewish Community Center on Manhattans Upper West Side, with spaces for worship, athletics and cultural programs, open to the public.

title: Teen Participant in Slender Man Stabbing to Be Released From Mental Hospital
